heading: Deaths
txt: Henry James Pye, English poet and politician (b. 1745)

entities.title: Henry James Pye
entities.description: Henry James Pye was an English poet, and Poet Laureate from 1790 until his death. His appointment owed nothing to poetic achievement, and was probably a reward for political favours. Pye was merely a competent prose writer, who fancied himself as a poet, earning the derisive label of poetaster.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lorenz Oken, German botanist, biologist, and ornithologist (b. 1779)

entities.title: Lorenz Oken
entities.description:
Lorenz Oken was a German naturalist, botanist, biologist, and ornithologist.
Oken was born Lorenz Okenfuss in Bohlsbach, Ortenau, Baden, and studied natural history and medicine at the universities of Freiburg and Würzburg. He went on to the University of Göttingen, where he became a Privatdozent, and shortened his name to Oken. As Lorenz Oken, he published a small work entitled Grundriss der Natu

heading: Deaths
txt: Macedonio Melloni, Italian physicist and academic (b. 1798)

entities.title: Macedonio Melloni
entities.description: Macedonio Melloni was an Italian physicist, notable for demonstrating that radiant heat has similar physical properties to those of light.

heading: Deaths
txt: Halfdan Kjerulf, Norwegian pianist and composer (b. 1815)

entities.title: Halfdan Kjerulf
entities.description: Halfdan Kjerulf was a Norwegian composer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lydia Koidula, Estonian poet and playwright (b. 1843)

entities.title: Lydia Koidula
entities.description: Lydia Emilie Florence Jannsen,, known by her pen name Lydia Koidula, was an Estonian poet. Her sobriquet means 'Lydia of the Dawn' in Estonian. It was given to her by the writer Carl Robert Jakobson. She is also frequently referred to as Koidulaulik – 'Singer of the Dawn'.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Henry Newman, English cardinal and theologian (b. 1801)

entities.title: John Henry Newman
entities.description: John Henry Newman was an English theologian, scholar and poet, first an Anglican priest and later a Catholic priest and cardinal, who was an important and controversial figure in the religious history of England in the 19th century. He was known nationally by the mid-1830s, and was canonised as a saint in the Catholic Church in 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Enrico Betti, Italian mathematician and academic (b. 1813)

entities.title: Enrico Betti
entities.description: Enrico Betti Glaoui was an Italian mathematician, now remembered mostly for his 1871 paper on topology that led to the later naming after him of the Betti numbers. He worked also on the theory of equations, giving early expositions of Galois theory. He also discovered Betti's theorem, a result in the theory of elasticity.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eugenio María de Hostos, Puerto Rican-American  sociologist, philosopher, and lawyer (b. 1839)

entities.title: Eugenio María de Hostos
entities.description: Eugenio María de Hostos, known as "El Gran Ciudadano de las Américas", was a Puerto Rican educator, philosopher, intellectual, lawyer, sociologist, novelist, and Puerto Rican independence advocate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Khudiram Bose, Indian Bengali revolutionary (b. 1889)

entities.title: Khudiram Bose
entities.description: Khudiram Bose was an Indian revolutionary from Bengal Presidency who opposed British rule of India. For his role in the Muzaffarpur Conspiracy Case, along with Prafulla Chaki, he was sentenced to death and subsequently executed, making him one of the youngest martyrs of the Indian Independence Movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andrew Carnegie, Scottish-American businessman and philanthropist, founded the Carnegie Steel Company and Carnegie Hall (b. 1835)

entities.title: Andrew Carnegie
entities.description: Andrew Carnegie was a Scottish-American industrialist and philanthropist. Carnegie led the expansion of the American steel industry in the late 19th century and became one of the richest Americans in history. He became a leading philanthropist in the United States and in the British Empire. During the last 18 years of his life, he gave away ~$350 million to many charities, foundations, and univers

entities.title: Carnegie Steel Company
entities.description: Carnegie Steel Company was a steel-producing company primarily created by Andrew Carnegie and several close associates, to manage businesses at steel mills in the Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania area in the late 19th century. The company formed in 1892 and was subsequently sold in 1901 in one of the largest ever business transactions of the early 20th century, to become the major component of the United

entities.title: Carnegie Hall
entities.description: Carnegie Hall is a concert venue in Midtown Manhattan in New York City. It is at 881 Seventh Avenue, occupying the east side of Seventh Avenue between West 56th and 57th Streets.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Sumner, English philanthropist, founded the Mothers' Union (b. 1828)

entities.title: Mary Sumner
entities.description: Mary Sumner  was the founder of the Mothers' Union, a worldwide Anglican women's organisation. She is commemorated in a number of provinces of the Anglican Communion on 9 August.

entities.title: Mothers' Union
entities.description: Mothers’ Union is an international Christian charity that seeks to support families worldwide. Its members are not all mothers or even all women, as there are many parents, men, widows, singles and grandparents involved in its work. Its main aim is to support monogamous marriage and family life, especially through times of adversity.

heading: Deaths
txt: Blas Infante, Spanish historian and politician (b. 1885)

entities.title: Blas Infante
entities.description: Blas Infante Pérez de Vargas was a Spanish Andalucista politician, Georgist, writer, historian and musicologist, known as the father of Andalusian nationalism (Padre de la Patria Andaluza).

heading: Deaths
txt: Edith Wharton, American novelist and short story writer (b. 1862)

entities.title: Edith Wharton
entities.description: Edith Wharton was an American novelist, short story writer, and designer. Wharton drew upon her insider's knowledge of the upper class New York "aristocracy" to realistically portray the lives and morals of the Gilded Age. In 1921, she became the first woman to win the Pulitzer Prize in Literature, for her novel The Age of Innocence. She was inducted into the National Women's Hall of Fame in 1996.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jean Bugatti, German-Italian engineer (b. 1909)

entities.title: Jean Bugatti
entities.description: Jean Bugatti was an automotive designer and test engineer for Bugatti.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: Stefan Jaracz
entities.description: Stefan Jaracz was a Polish actor and theater producer. He served as the artistic director of Ateneum Theatre in Warsaw during the interwar period (1930–32), and within a short period raised its reputation as one of the leading voices for Poland's new intelligentsia, with groundbreaking productions of Danton's Death by Georg Büchner (1931), The Captain of Köpenick by Carl Zuckmayer (1932), as well

heading: Deaths
txt: Tazio Nuvolari, Italian race car driver and motorcycle racer (b. 1892)

entities.title: Tazio Nuvolari
entities.description: Tazio Giorgio Nuvolari was an Italian racing driver. He first raced motorcycles and then concentrated on sports cars and single-seaters. A resident of Mantua, he was known as 'Il Mantovano Volante' and nicknamed 'Nivola'. His victories—72 major races, 150 in all—included 24 Grands Prix, five Coppa Cianos, two Mille Miglias, two Targa Florios, two RAC Tourist Trophies, a Le Mans 24-hour race, and a

heading: Deaths
txt: Jackson Pollock, American painter (b. 1912)

entities.title: Jackson Pollock
entities.description: Paul Jackson Pollock was an American painter and a major figure in the abstract expressionist movement.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antanas Škėma, Lithuanian-American author, playwright, actor, and director (b. 1910)

entities.title: Antanas Škėma
entities.description: Antanas Škėma was a Lithuanian writer, playwright, stage actor and director. His best known work is the novel White Shroud.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Wahle, Austrian-American swimmer and coach (b. 1879)

entities.title: Otto Wahle
entities.description: Otto Wahle was an Austrian swimmer who took part in two Summer Olympic Games and won a total of three medals. Wahle coached the men's US swim team at the 1912 Olympics, and the men's US water polo team at the 1920 and 1924 Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Woodfull, Australian cricketer and educator (b. 1897)

entities.title: Bill Woodfull
entities.description: William Maldon Woodfull was an Australian cricketer of the 1920s and 1930s. He captained both Victoria and Australia, and was best known for his dignified and moral conduct during the tumultuous bodyline series in 1932–33. Trained as a schoolteacher, Woodfull was known for his benevolent attitude towards his players, and his patience and defensive technique as an opening batsman. Woodfull was not

heading: Deaths
txt: Miriam Licette, English soprano and educator (b. 1885)

entities.title: Miriam Licette
entities.description: Miriam Licette was an English operatic soprano whose career spanned 35 years, from the mid-1910s to after World War II. She was also a singing teacher, and created the Miriam Licette Scholarship.

heading: Deaths
txt: Max Theiler, South African-American virologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1899)

entities.title: Max Theiler
entities.description: Max Theiler was a South African-American virologist and physician. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1951 for developing a vaccine against yellow fever in 1937, becoming the first African-born Nobel laureate.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vicente Emilio Sojo, Venezuelan conductor and composer (b. 1887)

entities.title: Vicente Emilio Sojo
entities.description: Vicente Emilio Sojo was a Venezuelan musicologist, educator and composer, born in Guatire, Miranda.

heading: Deaths
txt: Frederic Calland Williams, British co-inventor of the Williams-Kilborn tube, used for memory in early computer systems (b. 1911)

entities.title: Frederic Calland Williams
entities.description: Sir Frederic Calland Williams,, known as F.C. Williams or Freddie Williams, was an English engineer, a pioneer in radar and computer technology.

entities.title: Williams tube
entities.description: The Williams tube, or the Williams–Kilburn tube after inventors Freddie Williams and Tom Kilburn, is an early form of computer memory. It was the first random-access digital storage device, and was used successfully in several early computers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Berta Ruck, Indian-born Welsh romance novelist (b. 1878)

entities.title: Berta Ruck
entities.description: Amy Roberta (Berta) Ruck, Mrs. Oliver Onions was an Indian-born Welsh writer of over 90 romance novels from 1905 to 1972. She also wrote short stories, an autobiography and two memoir-style works.

heading: Deaths
txt: J. G. Farrell, English author (b. 1935)

entities.title: J. G. Farrell
entities.description: James Gordon Farrell was an English-born novelist of Irish descent who spent much of his childhood in Ireland. He gained prominence for a series of novels known as "the Empire Trilogy", which deal with the political and human consequences of British colonial rule.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Robert, French lexicographer and publisher (b. 1910)

entities.title: Paul Robert (lexicographer)
entities.description: Paul Charles Jules Robert, usually called Paul Robert, was a French lexicographer and publisher, best known for his large Dictionnaire alphabétique et analogique de la langue française (1953), often called simply the Robert, and its abridgement, the Petit Robert (1967).

heading: Deaths
txt: Tom Drake, American actor and singer (b. 1918)

entities.title: Tom Drake
entities.description: Tom Drake was an American actor. Drake made films starting in 1940 and continuing until the mid-1970s, and also made TV acting appearances.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred A. Knopf Sr., American publisher, founded Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. (b. 1892)

entities.title: Alfred A. Knopf Sr.
entities.description: Alfred Abraham Knopf Sr. was an American publisher of the 20th century, and founder of Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. His contemporaries included the likes of Bennett Cerf and Donald Klopfer, and Frank Nelson Doubleday, J. Henry Harper and Henry Holt. Knopf paid special attention to the quality of printing, binding, and design in his books, and earned a reputation as a purist in both content and presentati

entities.title: Alfred A. Knopf
entities.description: Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. is an American publishing house that was founded by Alfred A. Knopf Sr. and Blanche Knopf in 1915. Blanche and Alfred traveled abroad regularly and were known for publishing European, Asian, and Latin American writers in addition to leading American literary trends. heading: Deaths
txt: János Drapál, Hungarian motorcycle racer (b. 1948)

entities.title: János Drapál
entities.description: János Drapál was a Grand Prix motorcycle road racer from Budapest. He had little chance to race in the Grand Prix world championships during the Cold War, but still won four Grand Prix races. Drapál had his best year in 1971 when he won the Yugoslavian Grand Prix and finished the year in seventh place in the 350cc world championship, riding a Yamaha. heading: Deaths
txt: Anne Ramsey, American actress (b. 1929)

entities.title: Anne Ramsey
entities.description: Angelina "Anne" Ramsey was an American actress. She is best known for her film roles as Mama Fratelli in The Goonies (1985) and as Mrs. Lift in Throw Momma from the Train (1987), the latter of which earned her nominations for an Academy Award and a Golden Globe Award.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Meillon, Australian actor (b. 1934)

entities.title: John Meillon
entities.description: John Meillon,, was an Australian character actor, known for many straight as well as comedy roles, he became most widely known internationally as Walter Reilly in the films Crocodile Dundee and Crocodile Dundee II. He also voiced advertisements for Victoria Bitter beer.

heading: Deaths
txt: J. D. McDuffie, American race car driver (b. 1938)

entities.title: J. D. McDuffie
entities.description: John Delphus McDuffie Jr.  was an American racing driver. He competed in the NASCAR Winston Cup Series from 1963 to 1991, collecting 106 top-10 finishes during his career, despite never finishing on the lead lap of any race in his career, and holding the record for the most starts in NASCAR's top level without a win with 653. He died in a racing accident during the Budweiser at The Glen at Watkins

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Cushing, English actor (b. 1913)

entities.title: Peter Cushing
entities.description: Peter Wilton Cushing, was an English actor best known for his roles in the Hammer Productions horror films of the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, and as Grand Moff Tarkin in the 1977 film Star Wars. His acting career spanned over six decades and included appearances in more than 100 films, as well as many television, stage and radio roles. Born in Kenley, Surrey, Cushing made his stage debut in 1935 and

heading: Deaths
txt: Phil Harris, American singer-songwriter and actor (b. 1904)

entities.title: Phil Harris
entities.description: Wonga Philip Harris was an American musician, actor and comedian. He was an orchestra leader and a pioneer in radio situation comedy, first with The Jack Benny Program, then in The Phil Harris-Alice Faye Show in which he co-starred with his wife, singer-actress Alice Faye, for eight years. Harris is also noted for his voice acting in animated films. As a voice actor, he played Baloo in The Jungle

txt: Rafael Kubelík, Czech conductor and composer (b. 1914)

entities.title: Rafael Kubelík
entities.description: Rafael Jeroným Kubelík, KBE was a Czech-born Swiss conductor and composer.

entities.title: Jean Papineau-Couture

heading: Deaths
txt: Percy Stallard, English cyclist and coach (b. 1909)

entities.title: Percy Stallard
entities.description: Percy Thornley Stallard was an English racing cyclist who reintroduced massed-start road racing on British roads in the 1940s.

heading: Deaths
txt: Galen Rowell, American photographer and mountaineer (b. 1940)

entities.title: Galen Rowell
entities.description: Galen Avery Rowell was a wilderness photographer, adventure photojournalist and climber. Born in Oakland, California, he became a full-time photographer in 1972.

heading: Deaths
txt: Armand Borel, Swiss-American mathematician and academic (b. 1923)

entities.title: Armand Borel
entities.description: Armand Borel was a Swiss mathematician, born in La Chaux-de-Fonds, and was a permanent professor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, United States from 1957 to 1993. He worked in algebraic topology, in the theory of Lie groups, and was one of the creators of the contemporary theory of linear algebraic groups.

entities.title: Mike Douglas
entities.description: Michael Delaney Dowd Jr., known as Mike Douglas, was an American "Big Band" era singer, entertainer, television talk show host of The Mike Douglas Show, and actor.

heading: Deaths

entities.title: George Furth
entities.description: George Furth was an American librettist, playwright, and actor.

txt: Eunice Kennedy Shriver, American activist, founded the Special Olympics  (b. 1921)

entities.title: Eunice Kennedy Shriver
entities.description: Eunice Mary Kennedy Shriver was an American philanthropist and a member of the Kennedy family. She was the founder of the Special Olympics, a sports organization for persons with physical and intellectual disabilities. For her efforts on behalf of the disabled, Shriver was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1984.

entities.title: Special Olympics
entities.description: Special Olympics is the world's largest sports organization for children and adults with intellectual disabilities and physical disabilities, providing year-round training and activities to 5 million participants and Unified Sports partners in 172 countries. entities.title: Red Bastien
entities.description: Rolland "Red" Bastien was an American professional wrestler.

heading: Deaths
txt: Raymond Delisle, French cyclist (b. 1943)

entities.title: Raymond Delisle
entities.description: Raymond Delisle was a French professional road bicycle racer. His sporting career began with ACBB Paris. He is the only rider to have won a stage of the Tour de France on 14 July, France's national day, while wearing the jersey of national champion.

heading: Deaths
txt: Yisrael Kristal, Polish-Israeli supercentenarian;  oldest living Holocaust survivor and one of the ten oldest men ever (b. 1903)

entities.title: Yisrael Kristal
entities.description: Yisrael Kristal was a Polish-Israeli supercentenarian recognized in 2014 as the oldest living Holocaust survivor. After the death of Yasutaro Koide, of Japan, on January 18, 2016, he was also recognized as the oldest living man in the world as well as one of the ten oldest men ever at his death at age 113 years and 330 days.

entities.title: V S Naipaul
entities.description: Sir Vidiadhar Surajprasad Naipaul, commonly known as V. S. Naipaul, and familiarly, Vidia Naipaul, was a Trinidad and Tobago-born British writer of works of fiction and nonfiction in English. He is known for his comic early novels set in Trinidad, his bleaker novels of alienation in the wider world, and his vigilant chronicles of life and travels. heading: Deaths
txt: Sergio Obeso Rivera, Mexican Roman Catholic cardinal (b. 1931)

entities.title: Sergio Obeso Rivera
entities.description: Sergio Obeso Rivera was a Mexican prelate of the Catholic Church. He was Archbishop of Xalapa from 1979 to 2007 after serving as Bishop of Papantla from 1971 to 1974 and then as coadjutor in Xalapa from 1974 to 1979. Pope Francis created him a cardinal on 28 June 2018.

heading: Deaths
txt: Trini Lopez, Mexican American singer and guitarist (b. 1937)

entities.title: Trini Lopez
entities.description: Trinidad López III was an American singer, guitarist, and actor. His first album included a cover version of Pete Seeger's "If I Had a Hammer", which earned a Golden Disc for him. His other hits included "Lemon Tree", "I'm Comin' Home, Cindy" and "Sally Was a Good Old Girl". He designed two guitars for the Gibson Guitar Corporation, which are now collectors’ items.
